div.div: The labelled data is processed in UploadTrainingDataÂ

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 228px; height: 1px; padding-top: 765px; margin-left: 931px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: CleanInputFunction creates 2 columns, one for stance detection and one for topic extraction. For topic extraction stop words are filtered. Both are converted to lower case, punctuation and special characters are replaced by spaces, duplicate whitespace is removed, the text is lemmatized (conversion to 'base' words), the text is tokenized, selected words are filtered and the output is returned

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 1px; height: 1px; padding-top: 620px; margin-left: 1045px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 24px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: nowrap;

div.div: Pre-processing

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 328px; height: 1px; padding-top: 798px; margin-left: 1232px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.div: TopicExtractionFunction takes text as input and returns 3 words to describe the topic. It can also produce visualizations as displayed in TopicExtraction. This process has 6 steps:

ol.li: Create BERT embeddings for the text
Run a clustering algorithm to get clusters about a similar topic
Each topic is represented with a bag-of-words
Use class-based TF-IDF to rank the words that are representative of / unique for that topic
Process the results from step 5 and return the top 3 words

div.div: This model has been tuned manually by analyzing how well the topics correspond to the given text (articles)

switch.text: TopicExtractionFunction takes text as input and returns...

div.div: Model training

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 188px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1260px; margin-left: 2111px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: TrainModel runs periodically and loads the latest training data from training_data_stance it then trains the stance detection algorithm, saves the model and uploads it for serverless inference

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 288px; height: 1px; padding-top: 790px; margin-left: 1631px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: Both the title and subjects go through a pre-processing layer followed by a BERT embedding (both using the same model as research has shown that this improves results). These embeddings are then concatenated and passed into a fully connected neural network. After attempting many configurations, the final architecture uses 2 layers, the first having 300 neurons and the second having 100. It is relatively small, but works will considering the limited training data. This is also why dropout was not used, as it would require a lot more data to train on. Finally, the model returns the stance for the given title and subject.

switch.text: Both the title and subjects go through a pre-pro...
